                                    • Chapter 4 Exercise 3

                                    Continuity of real-valued functions

                                    NOTE. In Exercises 4.10 through 4.28, all functions are real-valued.

                                    4.13

                                    Let f be continuous on [a,b] and let f(x)=0 when x is rational. Prove that f(x)=0 for every x in [a,b].

                                    Proof

                                    Assume there is p∈[a,b] such that f(p)≠0, let ε=|f(p)|/2>0, then given any δ>0, we can find some rational q∈(p−δ,p+δ)∩[a,b], and |f(p)−f(q)|>ε, this contradicts f being continuous.

                                    4.14

                                    Let f be continuous at the point a=(a1,a2,…,an) in Rn. Keep a2,a3,…,an fixed and define a new function g of one real variable by the equation

                                    g(x)=f(x,a2,…,an)

                                    Prove that g is continuous at the point x=a1.

                                    Proof

                                    For ∀ε>0, since f is continuous at a, there is δ>0 such that |f(z)−f(a)|<ε whenever |z−a|<δ, consider g(x) and let |x−a1|<δ, then z=(x,a2,…,an) satisfy |z−a|<δ, thus |g(x)−g(a1)|=|f(z)−f(a)|<ε, this means g is continuous at the point x=a1.

                                    4.15

                                    Show by an example that the converse of the statement in Exercise 4.14 is not true in general.

                                    Solution

                                    Let f:R2→R be defined as follows:

                                    f(x,y)={xyx2+y2,(x,y)≠(0,0)0,(x,y)=(0,0)

                                    Consider the point a=(0,0), function g1(x)=f(x,0)=0 is continuous at the point x=0, function g2(y)=f(0,y)=0 is continuous at the point y=0, but f is not continuous at a=(0,0), since f(1/n,1/n)=1/2 as n→∞.

                                    4.16

                                    Let f,g, and h be defined on [0,1] as follows:

                                    f(x)=g(x)=h(x)=0,x∈R−Qf(x)=1,g(x)=x,h(x)=1/n,x∈Q−{0},x=m/nf(0)=1,g(0)=0,h(0)=1

                                    Prove that f is not continuous anywhere in [0,1], that g is continuous only at x=0, and that h is continuous only at the irrational points in [0,1].

                                    Proof

                                    Let ε=1/2, then given any x∈[0,1] and any δ>0, the open ball (x−δ,x+δ)∩[0,1] will contain infinitely many rational points and irrational points, thus if x is rational, we can find a irrational point x′, if x is irrational, we can find a rational point x′, in both cases lead to |f(x)−f(x′)|=1>ε.

                                    Consider g at x=0, for any ε>0, we can choose δ=ε, if x−0<δ, then |g(x)−g(0)|=g(x)=x<δ=ε, thus g is continuous at 0. If a∈(0,1], let ε0=a/2>0, since in any ball B(a;δ)∩[0,1] with δ>0 there exists a irrational x′, such that |g(x′)−g(a)|=a>ε0, this means g is not continuous at a.

                                    Consider h, if x is a irrational point in [0,1], then for any ε>0, there is an integer N such that 1/N<ε, since x is irrational, for every integer 1≤n≤N we can find integer kn such that

                                    knn<x<kn+1n,∀1≤n≤N

                                    thus we get 2N points, each has the form kn/n or (kn+1)/n for integer n between 1 and N, let p be the point which is nearest to x and let δ=|x−p|, then in the ball B(x;δ) there is no rational points of the form a/b with b≤N, thus we can declare |h(x)−h(y)|<1/N<ε,∀y∈B(x;δ), this means h is continuous at x. Now if x is rational, then h(x)=1/n for some integer n≥1, given ε0=1/2n, in any ball B(x;δ) there are irrational points q which makes |h(x)−h(q)|=1/n>ε0, thus h is not continuous at x.

                                    4.17

                                    For each x in [0,1], let f(x)=x if x is rational, and let f(x)=1−x if x is irrational. Prove that:

                                    (a) f(f(x))=x for all x in [0,1].

                                    (b) f(x)+f(1−x)=1 for all x in [0,1].

                                    (c) f is continuous only at the point x=1/2.

                                    (d) f assumes every value between 0 and 1.

                                    (e) f(x+y)−f(x)−f(y) is rational for all x and y in [0,1].

                                    Proof

                                    Notice that if x∈[0,1] is rational, then 1−x is rational. If x is irrational, then so is 1−x.

                                    (a) If x∈Q∩[0,1], then f(f(x))=f(x)=x, if x is not rational, then f(f(x))=f(1−x)=1−(1−x)=x.

                                    (b) If x is rational, then f(x)+f(1−x)=x+1−x=1. If x is irrational, then f(x)+f(1−x)=1−x+1−(1−x)=1.

                                    (c) For ε>0, choose δ=ε, if |x−1/2|<δ, then |f(x)−1/2|=|x−1/2|<ε regardless of whether x is rational or not, so f is continuous at 1/2. For points p≠1/2, let ε0=|2p−1|/2>0, then given any δ>0, we can choose q in B(p;δ), which satisfy the two conditions below: (1) q is rational if p is irrational, q is irrational if p is rational;(2) |p+q−1|>ε0 since |p+q−1|→|2p−1| as q→p. Now |f(p)−f(q)|=|p+q−1|, and we conclude f is not continuous at p.

                                    (d) Given any value y∈[0,1], if y is rational, then f(y)=y; if y is irrational, then 1−y is irrational and f(1−y)=y.

                                    (e) If both x and y are rational, then the conclusion is obvious. If x is rational but y is not, then x+y is irrational and then

                                    f(x+y)−f(x)−f(y)=1−(x+y)−x−(1−y)=−2x∈Q

                                    If y is rational but x is not, the proof is similar. If both x and y are irrational, then x+y may be rational or irrational, thus

                                    f(x+y)−f(x)−f(y)={2(x+y)−2,x+y∈Q−1,x+y∉Q

                                    and the result is rational.

                                    4.18

                                    Let f be defined on R and assume that there exists at least one point x0 in R at where f is continuous. Suppose also that, for every x and y in R, f satisfies the equation f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y). Prove that there exists a constant a such that f(x)=ax for all x.

                                    Proof

                                    From f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y) we have f(0)=0 and f(−x)=−f(x) for x∈R. Also we have f(x)=f(x−r)+f(r)=f(x+x0−r)−f(x0)+f(r) for any r∈R, when x→r, or x+x0−r→x0, we have f(x+x0−r)→f(x0) since f is continuous at x0, and so f(x)→f(r), this shows f is continuous on R.

                                    Use f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y) we get f(m)=mf(1) for any m∈N, and f(−m)=−f(m)=−mf(1), thus f(m)=mf(1) for any integer m. If n∈N+, we have f(1)=nf(1/n), thus given any q∈Q, write q=m/n with n>0, then

                                    f(q)=f(mn)=mf(1n)=mnf(1)=qf(1)

                                    Let a=f(1), we see that f(x)=ax if x∈Q, the conclusion follows since f is continuous on R.

                                    4.19

                                    Let f be continuous on [a,b] and define g as follows: g(a)=f(a) and, for a<x≤b, let g(x) be the maximum value of f in the subinterval [a,x]. Show that g is continuous on [a,b].

                                    Proof

                                    g is monotonic increasing, choose some y∈[a,b], for any ε>0, as f is continuous at y, we can find some δ such that |f(x)−f(y)|<ε whenever x∈B(y;δ)∩[a,b], we conclude f(y)−ε<f(x)<f(y)+ε if x∈B(y;δ)∩[a,b]. Now consider the behavior of g(x) when x∈B(y;δ)∩[a,b].

                                    For any y−δ<x<y such that g(x)<g(y) , we can have f(y)>f(z) for z∈[a,x], or f(y)>g(x), as g(x)≥f(x)>f(y)−ε, and on the interval [x,y] f is restricted by f(y)+ε, thus g(y)≤f(y)+ε, or f(y)≥g(y)−ε, so we get

                                    g(y)−2ε≤f(y)−ε<g(x)<g(y)

                                    Similarly, for any y<x<y+δ such that g(y)<g(x), we can get

                                    g(y)<g(x)<g(y)+2ε

                                    So whenever x∈B(y;δ)∩[a,b], we have |g(x)−g(y)|<2ε, so g is continuous.

                                    4.20

                                    Let f1,…,fm be m real-valued functions defined on a set S in Rn. Assume that each fk is continuous at the point a of S. Define a new function f as follows: For each x in S, f(x) is the largest of the m numbers f1(x),…,fm(x). Discuss the continuity of f at a.

                                    Solution

                                    For ∀ε>0, suppose f(a)=fk(a) for some integer k between 1,…,m, first suppose k is the only integer which makes f(a)=fk(a), and without loss of generality we set k=1, let

                                    ε0=min{ε,f(a)−f2(a),…,f(a)−fm(a)}/2

                                    since each fi is continuous at a, we can find a δ such that whenever |x−a|<δ, we can have |fi(x)−fi(a)|<ε0, this means f(x)=f1(x) on B(a;δ), so f is continuous at a.

                                    If there is more than one integer k that makes f(a)=fk(a), we prove f is still continuous at a for the case of two integers, and cases for more than two integers up to m integers can be proved similarly. Suppose we have fl(a)=fk(a) for k≠l, then choose ε0 in the way below:

                                    ε0=min(ε,mini≠k,l{f(a)−fi(a)})2

                                    find a δ such that whenever |x−a|<δ, we have |fi(x)−fi(a)|<ε0, then the value of f is only determined by fk,fl on B(a;δ), since

                                    fl(a)−ε0<fl(x)<fl(a)+ε0fk(a)−ε0<fk(x)<fk(a)+ε0

                                    we have f(a)−ε0<f(x)<f(a)+ε0 when x∈B(a;δ), thus |f(x)−f(a)|<ε0<ε, and f is continuous at a.

                                    4.21

                                    Let f:S→R be continuous on an open set S in Rn, assume that p∈S, and assume that f(p)>0. Prove that there is an n-ball B(p;r) such that f(x)>0 for every x in the ball.

                                    Proof

                                    Let ε=f(p)/2>0, then there is r>0 such that |f(x)−f(p)|<ε whenever |x−p|<r, or f(x)>f(p)−ε=f(p)/2>0 whenever x∈B(p;r).

                                    4.22

                                    Let f be defined and continuous on a closed set S in R. Let

                                    A={x:x∈S and f(x)=0}.

                                    Prove that A is a closed subset of R.

                                    Proof

                                    Let p be an accumulation point of A, assume p∉A, then f(p)≠0, since f is continuous on S, f is continuous at p and thus there exists a ball B(p;r) such that f(x)≠0 for every x in the ball, thus B(p;r)∩A=∅, a contradiction. Thus p∈A and A is closed.

                                    We can also use Theorem 4.24, and the fact that A=f−1({0}), and {0} is a closed set in R to get A being closed.

                                    4.23

                                    Given a function f:R→R, define two sets A and B in R2 as follows:

                                    A={(x,y):y<f(x)},B={(x,y):y>f(x)}.

                                    Prove that f is continuous on R if, and only if, both A and B are open subsets of R2.

                                    Proof

                                    First suppose f is continuous on R, let p=(a,b)∈A, then b<f(a), let ε=(f(a)−b)/2>0, there is δ>0 such that |f(x)−f(a)|<ε whenever x∈(a−δ,a+δ), we can make δ<ε, consider the ball B(p;δ), for ∀(x,y)∈B(p;δ), we have |x−a|<δ and |y−b|<δ, thus

                                    y<b+δ<b+ε=f(a)+b2=f(a)−ε<f(x)

                                    which means (x,y)∈A, thus the ball B(p;δ)⊆A and A is open. Similarly we can prove B is open.

                                    Conversely, if A and B are open, choose x0∈R, for any ε>0, consider the point p=(x0,f(x0)−ε/2)∈A, as A is open, there is a r″>0 which makes the ball B(p;r)⊆A, this means if x∈(x0−r″,x0+r″), then f(x)≥f(x0)−ε/2, similarly, from B being open we can find a r′>0 and x∈(x0−r′,x0+r′) means f(x)≤f(x0)+ε/2. Let r=min(r′,r″) we get

                                    f(x0)−ε2≤f(x)≤f(x0)+ε2,∀x∈(x0−r,x0+r)

                                    this means |f(x)−f(x0)|<ε for all x in (x0−r,x0+r), thus f is continuous at x0. The conclusion follows as x0 is arbitrarily chosen.

                                    4.24

                                    Let f be defined and bounded on a compact interval S in R. If T⊆S, the num

                                    Ωf(T)=sup{f(x)−f(y):x∈T,y∈T}

                                    is called the oscillation (or span) of f on T. If x∈S, the oscillation of f at x is defined to be the number

                                    ωf(x)=limh→0+Ωf(B(x;h)∩S).

                                    Prove that this limit always exists and that ωf(x)=0 if, and only if, f is continuous at x.

                                    Proof

                                    Since f is bounded, Ωf(T) exists for any T⊆S, if we define an=Ωf(B(x;1/n)∩S) , then {an} is a monotonic decreasing sequence bounded below by 0, thus limn→∞an exists, and it is easy to see that ωf(x)=limn→∞an.

                                    If f is continuous at x, then given ∀ε>0, there is δ>0 such that |f(y)−f(x)|<ε/2 whenever |y−x|<δ, this means

                                    Ωf(B(x;δ)∩S)<|f(x)+ε/2−(f(x)−ε/2)|=ε

                                    thus ωf(x)=0. Conversely, ωf(x)=0 means that given ∀ε>0, there is δ>0 such that Ωf(B(x;δ)∩S)<ε, if y∈B(x;δ)∩S, we have

                                    |f(y)−f(x)|≤Ωf(B(x;δ)∩S)<ε

                                    thus f is continuous at x.

                                    4.25

                                    Let f be continuous on a compact interval [a,b]. Suppose that f has a local maximum at x1 and a local maximum at x2. Show that there must be a third point between x1 and x2 where f has a local minimum. NOTE: To say that f has a local maximum at x1 means that there is a 1-ball B(x1) such that f(x)≤f(x1) for all x in B(x1)∩[a,b]. Local minimum is similarly defined.

                                    Proof

                                    Without loss of generality, we assume x1<x2 and find two 1-balls B(x1;r1) and B(x2;r2) with 0<r1,r2<(x2−x1)/2 and satisfy

                                    f(x)≤f(x1),x∈B(x1;r1)∩[a,b]f(x)≤f(x2),x∈B(x2;r2)∩[a,b]

                                    the interval [x1,x2] is compact and f is continuous on [x1,x2], thus by Theorem 4.28 there exists a point x3∈[x1,x2] such that f(x3)=inff([x1,x2]). If x3=x1, this means f(x) is constant in B(x1)∩[x1,x2], since f(x)≤f(x1) and f(x1)≤f(x) for all x∈B(x1)∩[x1,x2], then we can let x3=x1+r1/2 and still satisfy f(x3)=inff([x1,x2]). Similarly we can move x3 smaller than x2 if originally x3=x2. Thus we conclude there exists a point x3∈(x1,x2) such that f(x3)=inff([x1,x2]). Now let r=min(x3−x1,x2−x3), the ball B(x3;r)⊆[x1,x2] and f(x3)≤f(x) for all x∈B(x3;r), which means f has a local minimum at x3.

                                    4.26

                                    Let f be a real-valued function, continuous on [0,1], with the following property: For every real y, either there is no x in [0,1] for which f(x)=y or there is exactly one such x. Prove that f is strictly monotonic on [0,1].

                                    Proof

                                    We have f(0)≠f(1), suppose f(0)<f(1), and we assume f is not strictly monotonic increasing on [0,1], then there exist x,y∈[0,1] such that x<y and f(x)≥f(y), we further get f(x)>f(y) since x is the only value for f to get f(x). We also have x<1 and y>0, and either f(0)>f(y) or f(0)<f(y).

                                    If f(0)>f(y), then f(1)>f(y) and f(x)>f(y) and x<y<1. We can choose ε>0 such that f(y)+ε<f(x) and f(y)+ε<f(1), then there shall be a∈(x,y) and b∈(y,1) such that f(a)=f(b)=f(y)+ε, this is a contradiction to f being one-to-one. If f(0)<f(y), then f(0)<f(x) and f(y)<f(x) and 0<x<y. We can choose ε>0 such that f(0)<f(x)−ε and f(y)<f(x)−ε, then there shall be a∈(0,x) and b∈(x,y) such that f(a)=f(b)=f(x)−ε, this is a contradiction to f being one-to-one.

                                    In conclusion, suppose f(0)<f(1), then f must be strictly monotonic increasing on [0,1]. Similarly, suppose f(0)>f(1), then f must be strictly monotonic decreasing on [0,1].

                                    4.27

                                    Let f be a function defined on [0,1] with the following property: For every number y, either there is no x in [0,1] for which f(x)=y or there are exactly two values of x in [0,1] for which f(x)=y.

                                    (a) Prove that f cannot be continuous on [0,1]

                                    (b) Construct a function f which has the above property.

                                    (c) Prove that any function with this property has infinitely many discontinuities on [0,1].

                                    Proof

                                    (a) Assume f is continuous on [0,1], let M=supf([0,1]) and m=inff([0,1]), then exists a,b∈[0,1] such that f(a)=M,f(b)=m, then there exists a′,b′∈[0,1] such that f(a)=f(a′)=M and f(b)=f(b′)=m. Obviously M>m, otherwise there are four points which has equal function value, thus a,a′,b,b′ are four distinct points, since f has a local maximum both at a and at a′, by Exercise 4.25 f has a local minimum at some c between a and a′, and m≤f(c)<M.

                                    If one of b,b′ lies outside the interval between a and a′, for example, a<a′<b, then there are three points which has function value (M+f(c))/2, one between a and c, one between a′ and c, and one between a′ and b. Other cases when b<a<a′, or the interchange of a′ and a, the interchange of b′ and b, can be proved similarly.

                                    If a<b,b′<a′ or a′<b,b′<a, then f has a local maximum at some point d between b and b′, and M≥f(d)>m, consider the value (m+f(d))/2, we can still find at least three distinct points which has function value of it.

                                    We derived a contradiction as long as we assume f is continuous.

                                    (b) Let Q∩[0,1]={q1,q2,…} and define f on [0,1] as follows:

                                    f(x)={n,x=q2n or x=q2n+1x,x∈[0,1/2]−Q1−x,x∈[1/2,1]−Q

                                    (c) LEFT TO BE DONE.

                                    4.28

                                    In each case, give an example of a function f, continuous on S and such that f(S)=T, or else explain why there can be no such f.

                                    a)S=(0,1),T=(0,1].b)S=(0,1),T=(0,1)∪(1,2).c)S=R1,T=the set of rational numbers.d)S=[0,1]∪[2,3],T={0,1}.e)S=[0,1]×[0,1],T=R2.f)S=[0,1]×[0,1],T=(0,1)×(0,1).g)S=(0,1)×(0,1),T=R2.

                                    Solution

                                    (a) f(x)=sin⁡(πx).

                                    (b) No, since S is connected and T is not.

                                    (c) No, since S is connected and T is not.

                                    (d) f(x)=0,x∈[0,1] and f(x)=1,x∈[2,3].

                                    (e) No, since S is compact and T is not.

                                    (f) No, since S is compact and T is not.

                                    (g) f(x,y)=(cot⁡πx,cot⁡πy).
